title: Cat. 43  Staircase, 1891
publication_title: The Lithographs of James McNeill Whistler: The Digital Edition
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section body" id="body"> 431891Way: 37  
Levy: 62  
Transfer lithograph, drawn on coarse-grained transfer paper  
Ink color: black  
Signature: printed butterfly, lower right  
One state; image size: 184 × 163 mm  
Number of impressions listed by Way: 4  
Printer: Way  
Watermarks: 119, 284  
Stone: probably erased in 1891; certainly by 1896

When Whistler drew this view of a foyer, probably somewhere within the Hôtel Colbert, he selected a more coarsely grained transfer paper than he had used for his other two drawings of the same site (cat. 41 and cat. 42). The resulting image is somewhat difficult to read. According to T. R. Way, the stone was “destroyed after very few impressions,” suggesting that neither artist nor printer judged the lithograph a complete success. Nevertheless, Whistler was willing to have Staircase included in Way’s 1896 catalogue, and he signed at least two impressions. Way (1905) recorded only four impressions of the print; this number is too low, as at least eight have been located to date.

Chicago: AIC, grayish white chine (204 × 186 mm) mounted on ivory plate paper (413 × 317 mm); MWC, cream laid paper (240 × 185 mm), signed; Palmer, cream laid paper (240 × 184 mm). Glasgow: HAG, grayish ivory chine (206 × 168 mm) mounted on ivory plate paper (210 × 168 mm; maximum dimensions including tab with signature). London: BM, grayish white chine (204 × 168 mm) mounted on white plate paper (383 × 284 mm). Washington: FGA, grayish ivory chine (204 × 168 mm) mounted on ivory plate paper (383 × 282 mm); NGA, grayish ivory laid paper (239 × 180 mm).  
Nesta R. Spink, Harriet K. Stratis, Martha Tedeschi

</section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">Way (1905) identified this scene only as ‘the hall of a house.’

Although there were no impressions of Staircase in the artist’s estate at the time of his death (GUL LB6; transcribed in MacDonald (1988), p. 40), Rosalind Birnie Philip either acquired one during his lifetime or did so after 1903; she gave a signed impression to Glasgow University in 1935.

</section><section id="figures">Cat. 43, only state. The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of the Crown Family in honor of James N. Wood, 2004.569.

</section>
